prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Legal Bases Used by the Courts for the Protection of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: It has been argued that confidential information should not be seen as a form of property, but, in order to further the interests of a competitive market, is better characterized using features of equity and the common law.[1] The very fact that land is physical makes it a scarce resource: there is only a finite amount of land on earth. Knowledge, on the other hand, is not a scarce resource. It is infinite in time and space, and it can be shared by any number of people without depleting its value.

However, although information itself may be infinite, the development of confidential business information requires the use of labour and skill, and this renders the information scarce and thus valuable. Value is acquired by reason of the fact that the information is not accessible to and cannot be enjoyed by any except those to whom the creator of the idea chooses to impart the information. This is true of all forms of intellectual property as there is an infinite number of expressions or forms of ideas just as there are of ideas themselves.
D. Vaver, “Civil Liability: Trade Secrets in Canada” (1980-81), 5 C.B.L.J. 253 at pp. 261-2.
